stream_context.summary: The stream focused on implementing new gameplay mechanics for a level. Kaze programmed a rideable 'soap bar' platform, debugged its physics, and created a custom bubble particle trail for it. He then developed a corresponding oil slick puzzle, creating an innovative iridescent visual effect using procedural vertex colors that can be 'cleaned' by the soap. The team's new design for the star select screen was also discussed.

development_findings.summary: The team is redesigning the star select screen to feature small 3D panoramas for each level to convey its atmosphere, preferring 3D models over pre-rendered images to save ROM space and improve scaling on emulators.
development_findings.quote: So this is the new idea for the star select. Basically, each level is gonna have a very small panorama that shows the vibe of the level.

development_findings.summary: A new 'soap bar' rideable platform is being developed. It functions like a surfable shell but shrinks and disappears over time.
development_findings.quote: We're gonna have a soul bar here, and you can stand on the soul bar and ride it kinda like a Koopa, like a Koopa shell.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is using his custom, more efficient particle engine to create effects like bubble trails, as the original SM64 engine is too inefficient for rendering many particles.
development_findings.quote: I have my own particle system. The original particle system is really bad because it overloads the texture every time. So rendering 10 bubbles like this would load the bubble texture 10 times.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has implemented a core physics improvement that allows Mario to consistently wall jump on steep surfaces that were previously impossible in the original game.
development_findings.quote: In Mario 64 on a wall like this, you can't jump on it. You will get rejected from it. But I fixed that.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is implementing a mechanic where players use the soap bar to clean up oil slicks, achieved technically by dynamically erasing an alpha mask on the oil texture.
development_findings.quote: We could have a normal oil texture and then an alpha mask and if you go over the thing the alpha mask like slowly fills up.

development_findings.summary: To create a visually interesting oil slick, Kaze implemented a rainbow iridescence effect by procedurally changing the vertex colors based on camera angle and vertex position, creating a dynamic shine on the N64 hardware.
development_findings.quote: I could just use the yaw and the pitch of the camera and the position of the vertex to generate a random hue and put it on here.

development_findings.summary: Kaze debugged an issue where a variable to offset Mario's position wasn't working, discovering it was because of a fundamental change he made to how the game's camera updates relative to Mario's state.
development_findings.quote: The numkeys variable clearly doesn't work. [...] Oh, I know why. It's because I synced the camera movement to Mario's update.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes his fan games should be self-contained and not require knowledge of his previous work to be enjoyed.
context_findings.quote: Making your story connected to your other fan games that probably a lot of people that play this new fan game haven't played. It's just kind of bad if you ask me.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's design philosophy for the final level is to prioritize an epic feel and accessibility over extreme difficulty.
context_findings.quote: It's going to feel epic, but it's not going to be super difficult because people need to be able to beat it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a strong and complete disinterest in the return of the E3 gaming expo.
context_findings.quote: I don't care. I don't give a shit. Not even a little bit.

context_findings.summary: Kaze shares a personal and disturbing experience with online harassment, noting the unusual and severe nature of the threat.
context_findings.quote: I have gotten a rape threat. That's insane. That's never happened to me before. This is like so rare to get that. Like death threats? Shoot, everyone's gotten some of those.

context_findings.summary: Kaze describes his internal thought process as being abstract and logical, requiring a conscious translation into spoken language rather than thinking directly in English or German.
context_findings.quote: I think my thinking patterns are more closely to action. Just a bunch of logical contractions. And then I have to translate it to English if I want to talk to people.

context_findings.summary: Kaze alludes to a backstory or reason for a 'monkeys thing' in the game but does not elaborate further.
context_findings.quote: There is a reason for the monkeys thing. Don't worry about it.

biobak.summary: Biobak created a concept mockup for a new star select screen, featuring small panoramic scenes for each level, which Kaze prefers over his own initial ideas.
biobak.quote: Biobak had this here, which I think works a lot better already.

biobak.summary: Biobak requested that the bubble particles from the soap bar fade to white as they disappear, a feature Kaze then implemented.
biobak.quote: This is what Biobak has asked for.

biobak.summary: Biobak gave final approval on the iridescent, rainbow-like visual effect for the oil slick Kaze had developed.

zeina.summary: Zeina, Kaze's spouse, was at work during most of the stream but joined the chat near the end.
zeina.quote: Hello Zeina we're making soap and discussing microwaves

key_stories.title: Creating the Iridescent Oil Slick
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed to create a dynamic oil slick effect. After his initial attempt failed, he developed an innovative solution using procedural vertex colors to create a rainbow iridescence that mimics a reflective surface, a challenging feat on the N64.
key_stories.challenge: How to create a visually appealing, reflective-looking oil slick on N64 hardware that can also be dynamically 'cleaned up' by the player.
key_stories.process: Kaze first considered a simple texture but wanted a more dynamic, reflective look. He dismissed normal maps due to technical limitations with alpha masks. He then prototyped a novel idea to shift the hue of the texture's vertices based on camera angle. After an initial failed attempt that looked 'genuinely awful', he refined the algorithm, texture, and color saturation, eventually producing a result he and his team were happy with.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully created a shimmering, rainbow-colored oil slick by manipulating vertex colors based on camera angle. The effect was approved by Biobak and serves as the puzzle element to be cleaned by the new soap bar mechanic.
key_stories.key_quote: Wow this looks terrible, oh my god this looks so bad. I absolutely hate this.

key_stories.title: The Disappearing Soap Bar and Custom Particles
key_stories.summary: Kaze developed a new rideable soap bar mechanic. The process involved not only programming the object's physics and shrinking behavior but also creating a custom, efficient particle system to generate a visually appealing bubble trail that met the team's design goals.
key_stories.challenge: To implement a new rideable 'soap bar' object that shrinks over time and leaves a visually satisfying bubble trail.
key_stories.process: Kaze first implemented the basic riding physics. He then debugged several issues, including inverted normals and correctly offsetting Mario's position as the soap shrinks. For the visual effect, he decided against the inefficient native SM64 particle system and built the bubble trail using his own engine. He iterated on the bubble's appearance, incorporating Biobak's feedback to make them fade to white before vanishing.
key_stories.outcome: A fully functional soap bar was created that players can ride, which shrinks and disappears over time. It leaves a custom trail of pink, semi-transparent bubbles that fade to white, created using a more efficient, custom-built particle engine.
key_stories.key_quote: I have my own particle system. The original particle system is really bad because it overloads the texture every time.
